title: VA Disability Benefits Overview
content:
VA disability compensation offers monthly benefits to Veterans for service-connected disabilities. A service-connected disability is a condition that was caused by, made worse by, or resulted from military service. The VA assigns disability ratings from 0% to 100% based on the severity of the condition.

Key Points:
1. You can file a claim online through VA.gov
2. You'll need medical evidence of your current condition
3. Service records showing the event or injury
4. A nexus linking the current condition to service

Common Types of Claims:
- Direct Service Connection
- Secondary Service Connection
- Presumptive Service Connection
- Aggravation

The VA uses Compensation & Pension (C&P) exams to evaluate disabilities. These exams are crucial for determining your disability rating.

title: Understanding C&P Exams
content:
A Compensation and Pension (C&P) exam is a medical examination of a Veteran's disability, performed by a VA healthcare provider or a VA-contracted provider. The exam is used to gather evidence for a Veteran's disability claim.

Preparing for Your C&P Exam:
1. Bring relevant medical records
2. Be honest about your symptoms
3. Describe your worst days
4. Explain how the disability affects daily life

After the exam, the examiner will write a report that the VA will use to help determine:
- If your disability is service-connected
- The severity of your disability
- Your disability rating
